reviews.review_msg: She's one of the nicest profs you'll ever meet and also cares about her students. Overall, she was super helpful and making sure the course content was clear.

Excellent prof. Classes were interesting and informative, and the the tutorials were engaging (students were more than ready to contribute). A lot of reading is assigned, but she tells you at the beginning of the semester that you don't need to do all of it. I didn't find this course to be as demanding as I had expected, though not easy either.

Dr. Ayers was awesome! Extremely informative, very passionate about the course. It was her first time teaching SA203 and she was incredible. Definitely recommend her as a prof; there is a fair few readings but she doesn't check if you did them.
The best prof in the SFU Polisci department.

Amazing African Political Economy class! Prof. Ayers did an incredible job, presenting 'the stories' about Africa from an African perspective; different approach from the Eurocentric view that is presented in Western societies. This course is a must for everyone who's interested in having an objective view on the African continent.Thank you Alison!

Both she and Liz the TA are great but both are also tough markers, so you can't just squeak by in this class.  You have to do the readings and understand the theories.  Marks hard on the final but was fair on the paper. The paper is due really early in the course,so if your topic is from the latter half of the course you are at a disadvantage.

Global Political Economy - Great Prof super engaging and clear! She is a fair marker. If her TA is Elizabeth Blackwood your set she is amazing too! Dr. Ayers plays a lot of documentaries which helps, and she lectures and sends her notes if ask her!

Dr. Ayers is an amazing professor, who understands the material inside out and is interested in the student thinking critically on the topics covered each week. She cares for the student's learning process and uses all types of pedagogic tools for the student to grasp the concepts. SFU is lucky to have her and I am lucky to have her as a Prof.

Alison is an excellent professor that struck an excellent balance between lecture, discussion, and multimedia in her seminar.  I honestly learned more in her class than any other class I've taken.  Taking her course has led me to consider a masters in GPE, which was not on my radar before.  Discussion was always relevant and concise.

Alison herself is a great lecturer but she did little to control our seminar.  People went off topic for an hour on things that had nothing to do with the material and she did nothing to bring the discussion back to the material I paid to learn.

Definitely a fantastic teacher.  Her TA was a hard marker and the reading load was fairly heavy.  I have friends who took the course with Logan Masilamani and did way better in terms of grades but she is a better teacher in my opinion.

Best teacher ever! The classes are like a seminar, and keeps students engaged all the time. The readings are mind blowing and life changing. She is very unique and original in thoughts, organization and materials. This class is a must! Thank you, Alison!

Brilliant Prof.! By far the best professor I have ever had. Her lectures are engaging, the material she provides is thought provoking and opens new mental horizons, and her teaching style/ability is second to none. I will even go as far as saying that her class can be life altering, so def. if you can, take her class!
Very thoughtful instructor

Great class, teacher, TA! One of the few courses in SFU which shows a different (critical) prospective of GPE. Teacher very knowledgeable, approachable, fun. Course very well structured. Fair grades! A course that should be taken by every serious political science student.

Great professor, great TA (Elizabeth Blackwood)interesting class. Movies at the end of the class were great for people like me who hate being lectured to for 3 hours straight (and I actually learned a lot from the movies). Definitely take this class with her!
great

One of the best profs I've had. Clear, accessible for help, encourages in-class discussion. Expectations for tests, presentations, and papers are well outlined - no surprise grades! Course material is all critical theory - which is great because most development courses aren't. Showed documentaries every seminar, a great change of pace.
Alison is very knowledgeable in the field of GPE/IPE.  She puts a lot of effort into the preparation for her courses.  My only criticism is that she does not control her seminar very well.

Very nice, very helpful. Interesting class, there is no denying that it is quite radical, the readings did have weeks where there were fair presentations of both sides. However, it seemed like there was a lot of criticizing. Didn't look at prescription-to-situation ideas very often either.

This class was extremely helpful in making clear the economic system we are currently engaged in. I don't feel that her class was biased, as the syllabus was comprehensive and included thinkers of all perspectives. It also seems a little outdated to be criticizing this prof for having a political/social perspective. She should be praised!

I am almost done my degree and this class is the best I've taken. I have heard claims that she is biased but this is simply not true. I'm not 'left', but found this course fair and respective of diverse opinions. Yes it includes critical readings, but there are many that represent mainstream pol/econ and both texts are liberal in perspective.

Very nice prof. Im an economics student with a Political Science background and figured this class would be easy. Her readings are very biased with all the key readings based on a critical Marxist perspective. She explained what the liberal perspective was at the beginning of the course then simply criticized it the rest of the course. Not balanced
She is biased in her teaching indeed.  She only interjected in the seminar to express her marxist persuasions.  The course  definitely needs some more balance.  An extremely friendly woman.

Alison was absolutely incredible. While I'll agree with other comments about the heavy workload, at the same time the course content helped make this class excellent and it is well worth spending time on. This is one of those classes that deeply change your perspective on the world and forever stay in your mind.

Ayers is by far the best prof I have had at SFU. The course covers a wide range of readings, from conservative  to radical. This course really opened my eyes and covers a much broader range of perspectives than any course at SFU. Highly recommended for students who want to broaden their perspective. SFU needs more profs like Ayers.

The BEST professor in the department, and the highlight of my BA degree at SFU.By introducing the various theoretical perspectives in the discipline and encouraging in-class debate and analysis, her teaching style fosters intellectual growth, and a well-rounded understanding of issues. Ayers is passionate, committed, fair, and extremely insightful.

Re: Supposed "bias." In no other class have I ever read such a variety of thinkers: from Smith to Hayek to Friedman to Marx to Lenin and everything in between. It's called education and it usually involves something other than just having your existing biases confirmed. There is no prof at SFU that is as fair to as many differing views as Ayers.

Honestly the BEST class I have ever taken. Students read and learn about the mainstream pol-econ theories/theorists for more than half the course, then critical perspectives are introduced, allowing the student to come to their own conclusions. I have never seen students so vibrant and inspired. Best professor I have ever had, NO question!
She is tough and so are her TAs.  If you want to mess up your GPA take the course with her.

Ayers has is the most engaging and inspirational professor i have ever come across. She truly truly cares about her students, and teaches the material with compassion and clarity that makes complicated ideas and difficult subjects completely manageable and even fun. the world would be a better place if more profs taught like her.
Best instructor in the department.  Excellent class, Informative readings, TAKE THIS CLASS!

One of the most engaging and insightful classes!  The seminar notes and docs were an excellent way of working through course material.  They facilitated great discussions and were a good way to get to know other students, making class actually fun! Alison is super  nice and helpful, and obviously brilliant.  Truly one of the BEST profs at SFU!

I can honestly say she is the most inspiring professor I have ever had, definitely a breath of fresh air to have someone so critical in our poli-sci dept. However, she is so friendly, kind and accessible to her students that regardless of your political leanings you will adore her.

Alison is a fantastic instructor.  She's one of few who actually care about her students; she will always be willing to meet with you, answer questions, and explain.  Class time is full of learning--which is a lot more than I can say about other teachers in the polisci department.  She's a real asset to political science and SFU.

Alison is a peach, also completely brilliant. I've also taken 447 with her, and although there is quite a lot of reading and a decent amount of work because of seminar notes, these things are extremely helpful in flushing out ideas, as well as connecting with the ideas of your fellow students. Truly inspiring, and totally accessible. No gripes.

Brilliant Professor--in every sense of the word. Respectful of your opinions, but challenges you intellectually and academically. Everything one could hope for from an educator. The level of discussion in this class, quality wise, was second to none. 
 
 The best class I took in my 4 years at SFU, full stop.
I agree she is critical but she is not fair to other perspectives, not at all.  She is a tough marker in general but god forbid you lean slightly to the right.
Be prepared to work hard.

She is extremely hard and demands a lot of your time.  The readings are very extensive and there are weekly assignments.  Mind you, you will be spending hours a week copying reserves and finding articles, on top of the text books you purchase.  Absolutely ridiculous.  I'm an A student and she gave me my first B-.

I love Dr. Ayers!! She is the best professor I have ever had. I thought the course was going to be boring (Africa in the Global Political Economy) but Ayers helped shed light on why Africa is in such a mess.
She is very subtle and softspoken. I loved her though, she opened new doors of understanding to me. Made Political economy understandable.

Tough class if no background in philosophy or theory. Ayers is great however and can explain complex theory so that undergrads can get it. She is critical, but also very fair to traditions she doesn't agree with. Every POL SCI student should have to take this course!

She is definitely on the critical side. Great professor, she is one of the best in POL SCI at SFU. The course dealt with Africa in the GPE. The course lays bare the liberal IPE conception that economics is a positive sum game.

She is a great professor. I felt encouraged when I had her class. She is willing to give a permit to student to do something that he/she wants if his/her work make Dr. Alison interest. I like this prof very much, and I'm the one who talk in her class all the time, and she is willing to tell what she know to her student.
she's a tough marker, but also a helpful professor - as long as you're there to learn, she's one of the best profs you'll ever get. if you're a slacker - (good luck!)
course was very interesting and Ted Cohen's text book was a god sent.  The prof is very interesting but she has no interest in actually helping her students and she is terrible with email.
Interesting material but grade was below my normal average.  Mid-term was easy but the TA marking the paper was a pain.
No Comments
tough class in general
